titleStmt.title: The number and names of all the kings of England & Scotland from the beginning of their governments, to this present. As also, the times when, and how long each of them reigned. Shewing how many of them came to untimely ends: eyther by imprisonment, banishment, famine, poyson, drowning, beheading, falling from horses, slaine in battells, murdered, or otherwise. By J.T.

Shewing how many of them came to untimely ends: eyther by imprisonment, banishment, famine, poyson, drowning, beheading, falling from horses, slaine in battells, murdered, or otherwise. By J.T.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE NVMBER AND NAMES OF ALL THE KINGS OF ENGLAND & SCOTLAND From the beginning of their Governments, to this preſent.
As alſo, the times when, and how long each of them Reigned.
SHEWING HOW MANY OF them came to untimely ends: eyther by Impriſonment, Baniſhment, Famine, Poyſon, Drowning, Beheading, Falling from Horſes, Slaine in Battells, Murdered, or otherwiſe.
LONDON, Printed by T. H. and are to be ſold by FRANCIS COLES, at his ſhop in the Old Bayly, 1650.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
MAny Writers do make doubt whether this Land had, ever any King called Bruce: ſame doe utterly deny that any ſuch man was but the moſt Authors doe off me that when Troy was ſpoyted and burnt by the Greekes, the
〈◊◊◊◊〉 , and there was married to a daughter of L • inu •
King of Fulcany, (now the Dukedome of Florence) by which Lady he had a ſon named Aſcanius, who was the Father of Silvous Poſthumus; that Silvin was the Father of Brute. Brute being but fifteen years old in fortunatly (as he in a forreſt was hunting) ſlow his Father Silvius with an arrow as he ſhot into a thicket, thinking he had ſhot is a Deer: for which he was baniſhed from that Countrey, and ſhipping himſelfe wish a good (or great) number of his followers be land d here and was the firſt King of this Land. This is the opinion of many ancient and learned men, and divers Writers doe oppoſe thoſe authors: but I am reſolved that ane King or other had Reigne here when it was firſt a Kingdome and becauſe this Land bears the ancient name of Britaine (or Brutaine) I do hold with ſuch Authors as for Brute doe hold with mee.

div.head: A Deſcription of all the Kings of ENGLAND, how long they raigned, and how many of them came to untimely ends.

list.head: The number and names of Kings.
list.item: 4 Madam raigned 40 yeares. Devoured by Wolves as he was hunting.
5 Mempricius raigned 20 yeares. Devoured by Wolves.
9 Bladud raigned 20 yeares. Brake his neck, in practiſing to fly from the top of Apollors Temple London, in playing the fowle or foole: he builded Bathe.
11 Q. Cordelia raigned 5 yeares. She was K. Leires Daughter, and ſlew her ſelfe in priſon.
19, 20 Farex and Perex raigned together. 50 yeares. Both murdered, Forex killed Porex, and their Mother killed Ferex.

30 Archigalle raigned 34 yeares. Theſe 4 Kings raigned promiſ-cuouſly, Archigalle was firſt crowned, depoſed, crowned againe, depoſed the ſecond time, crowned againe, raigned in all 34 yeares, in his Raigne began the firſt King of Scotland.

31 Elidurus raigned 34 yeares. Theſe 4 Kings raigned promiſ-cuouſly, Archigalle was firſt crowned, depoſed, crowned againe, depoſed the ſecond time, crowned againe, raigned in all 34 yeares, in his Raigne began the firſt King of Scotland.

32 Vigerius raigned 34 yeares. Theſe 4 Kings raigned promiſ-cuouſly, Archigalle was firſt crowned, depoſed, crowned againe, depoſed the ſecond time, crowned againe, raigned in all 34 yeares, in his Raigne began the firſt King of Scotland.

33 Peredurus raigned 34 yeares. Theſe 4 Kings raigned promiſ-cuouſly, Archigalle was firſt crowned, depoſed, crowned againe, depoſed the ſecond time, crowned againe, raigned in all 34 yeares, in his Raigne began the firſt King of Scotland.

41 Cortus raigned 20 yeares. In the ſhort time of 54 yeares, from the Raigne of Coylns the 41 King, to Lud the 64 King; this Land had 2 Kings! So there being ſuch diverſities and alteration of Times and Writers, that it is no reckoning true of the Raignes of Kings from Geruntius the 39 King to 〈◊〉 the 67 King, in whoſe time our Saviour was borne.
67 Cimbolinus raigned 21 yeares. Our Saviour was born in the firſt of Cimbelinus raign.
72 Lucius raigned 12 yeares. Lucius was our firſt Chriſtian King.
73 Severus raigned 18 yeares. Killed at Yorke.
75 Cauraſivas raigned 7 yeares. Slain by Alectus.
76 Alectus raigned 3 yeares. Slaine by Aſcleopidatus.
77 Aſcleopidatus raigned 2 yeares. By Coyle he was ſlaine.
81 Conſtantinus raigned 5 yeares. Theſe were Brothers, murdered, and both by ſtrife againſt each other.
82 Conſtans raigned 3 yeares. Theſe were Brothers, murdered, and both by ſtrife againſt each other.
83 Octavius raigned 54 yeares. Slaine by Octavius.
85 Conſtantius 2. raigned 20 yeares. Slaine by Gratian.
88 Vortiger raigned 6 yeares. Burnt with his Wife, houſe, and family.

div.p:
ABout this time. England was divided into ſeven Kingdomes▪ namely, 1. Kent, 2. South Saxons, 3. Weſt Saxons, 4. Eaſt-Saxons, 5. Northumbers, 6. Eaſt Angles,
and 7. Mercia: This diviſion began in the 455 yeare after Chriſts Incarnation (but it was not ſettled in 40 yeares after) heere was nothing but continuell contention amongſt theſe 7 ſhorers of this Monarchy, their miſgoverned Government laſted 398 yeares, there having raigned 91 petty Kings; but it was neare 600 yeares before this Land was againe ••• ed into one ſole Monarchy, under King Athelſtane, Anno 920.

list.item: 100 Cadwallador raigned 3 yeares. Dyed at Rome.
103 Eldeed raigned 9 yeares. Baniſhed by the Danes.

111 Hardicanut ••
raigned 3. yeares. This Tyrant dranke himſelfe dead at Lambeth, in memory whereof the marry Hock mundayes were kept yearely.
113 Harold 2. raigned 9 moneths. Slaine at Battle Abby in Suſſex.

div.head: In the yeare of our Lord 1066, William the Conqueror began his Raigne heere; Macolme the third being then King of SCOTLAND.

list.head: The number and names of Kings.
list.item: 115 William Rufus raigned 13 yeares. Slaine inſtead of a Deere in New-Forreſt.
120 John raigned 17 yeares. Poyſoned, as ſome ſay, at Swinſted Abby.
123 Edward the 2. raigned 19 yeares. Murdered at Barkley Caſtle.
125 Richard the 2. raigned 22 yeares. Murdered at Pomfrer Caſtle.
128 Henry the 6. raigned 57 yeares. Murdered in the Tower.
130 Edward the 5. raigned 0 yeares. Murdered in the Tower.
131 Richard the 3. raigned 2 yeares. Shine at Boſworth.

div.head: Scotland began to bee a Kingdome 339 yeares before our Saviours comming, and hath continued under the Government of 108 Kings, neare 2000 yeares, beginning with King FERGUS.

list.head: The number and names of Kings.
list.item: 1 Fergus raigned 25 yeares. Drowned in Ireland at Craigfergus.
2 Feritharius raigned 15 yeares. Murdered by one Ferlegus, a brothers ſon of Fergus.
7 Reutha raigned 14 yeares. Reutha gave off his Kingly ſway for a quiet life.
8 Thereus raigned 12 yeares. Baniſhed by his Nobles, and dyed at Yorke.
16 Evenus the 3. raigned 7 yeares. Dyed in priſon.
20 Dardauns raigned 4 yeares. Beheaded by his owne Subjects.
24 Conarus raigned 14 yeares. Dyed in priſon.
25 Ethodius raigned 33 yeares. Murdred by an Iriſh Harper.
27 Eonald the 1. and firſt Chriſtian King of Stotland.
28 Euthodius the 2. raigned 16 yeares. Murdered by his ſervants.
30 Nathalocus raigned 11 yeares. Murdered, and caſt into a Privy.
31 Findocus raigned 11 yeares. Murdered as he was hunting.
38 Fethalmachus raigned 3 yeares. Murdred by another Harper.
39 Eugenius the 1. raigned 3 yeares. Slaine. The Scots were baniſhed by the Ficts and Romanes 44 yeares.
52 Ferquhard raigned 12 yeares. Killed himſelfe in priſon.
53 Donald the 4. raigned 14 yeares. Drowned in the River Pay.
54 Ferquard the 2. raigned 18 yeares. Killed by a Wolfe.
55 Malauin raigned 20 yeares. Strangled by his wife, for which ſhe was burned.
56 Eugenius the 5. raigned 4 yeares. Slaine by the Picts.
63 Fergus the 3. raigned 3 yeares. Poyſoned by his Wife.
67 Dongallus raigned 7 yeares. Drowned in the River Spey.
70 Donald the 5. raigned 5 yeares. Slew himſelfe.
71 Conſtantine the 2. raigned 16 yeares. Slaine by the Danes.
75 Conſtantine the 3. raigned 40 yeares. Depoſed himſelfe.
76 Macolme 1. raigned 9 yeares. Murdered in Murray by his owne ſervants.
78 Duffus raigned 5 yeares. Murdered in the County of Murray.
80 Keneth the 3. raigned 24 yeares. Murdered by a woman.
83 Macolme the 2. raigned 30 yeares. Murdred by his Nobles.
84 Duncan the raigned 6 years. Murdred by Ma beth.
85 Mackbeth raigned 17 yeares. Slaine by Metcalma
86 Malcolme the 3. raigned 36 yeares. Slain at Anwick.
89 Donald the 7. crowned again, caſt into priſon, and his eyes put out, raigned 3 yeares.
94 William ſurnamed the Lion raigned 49 yeares.
96 Alexander the 3. raigned 37 y. Dyed with a fall from his horſe, Scotland without a King 7 yeares.
97 John Ballioll raigned 4 yeares. Expulſt by Edward King of England.
102 Robert the 3. raigned 16 yeares. Scotland without a King 18 yeares.
103 James the 1. raigned 30 yeares. Murdred by his Nobles.
104 Iames the 2. raigned 24 yeares. Slain at Roxbrough.
105 Iames the 3. raigned 29 yeares. Slaine at Banokſbourn.
106 Iames the 4. raigned 25 yeares Slaine at denfield
